bioghist.p: Eugene Carson Blake (1906-1985) was born in St. Louis. He graduated from Princeton University in 1928 and spent the following year teaching English in Forman College, Lahore, India (now Pakistan). He returned to his studies in 1929, spending a year at New College, Edinburgh, Scotland, and two years at Princeton Theological Seminary, where he received a Th.B. in 1932. Blake married Valina Gillespie in 1929. He served as pastor of churches in New York City, Albany, and Pasadena, California, from 1932-1951. In 1951 he was elected Stated Clerk of the General Assembly (PCUSA), a post he held until 1958. In 1958 the PCUSA became the UPCUSA, and Blake was elected Stated Clerk of the UPCUSA General Assembly; he served until 1966. From 1954-1957 he served as president of the National Council of Churches, and in 1966 he became general secretary to the World Council of Churches, from which he retired in 1972. Dr. Blake is noted for his contributions to the 1967 confessional revision in the Presbyterian Church, to the civil rights movement, to church union efforts, and to the WCC's world development activities, as well as for his leadership in the WCC's Programme to Combat Racism.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Eugene Carson Blake. Materials include: correspondence, subject files, photographs, scrapbooks, and printed matter. Papers including minutes, memoranda, reports, correspondence, press releases, bulletins and other printed matter from Blake's term as president of the National Council of Churches of Christ include materials related to the work of the general board and various committees, 1953-1957. Materials from his post retirement years (1970s and 1980s) include incoming and outgoing correspondence, clippings, printed material (for example, magazines featuring Blake); minutes of the Princeton Theological Seminary Board of Trustees; a copy of Blake's FBI file; and a transcript of an 1982 interview of Blake and Roswell Barnes about their 1956 trip to Russia. The Brackenridge files on Blake consist of articles, copies of Blake's notebooks and correspondence, drafts of manuscripts of his biography of Blake (some with Blake's annotations), reprints, speeches and transcripts of interviews. Other items include: photographs (many portraits of Blake, some with other religious leaders); scrapbooks (1906-1966) with clippings, photographs, bulletins, programs, school records, and some correspondence; scrapbook of citations and diplomas (1941-1966); oversized photo albums of Blake's Christmas visits to North East Air Command (1955) and Alaskan Command (1956); vestments; audiocassettes of sermons by others (including those given at Blake's funeral); an audiocassette of an interview of Blake; and a small number of personal files, including tax records, home insurance, and pension records.
